div.head: DESCRIPTION Of the takeing of PHERNAMBOVCQVE.
div.p: THE Valiant and renowned Generall H.C. LONCK, Å¿ailed out of Goeree with 8. Ships the 27 Iune 1629 and came vnder Tenerifa in the Canaries, where hee was in fight with the Armade of Don FREDERICO the 23. and 24. AuguÅ¿t. and the 4. September hee ariued in S. Vincent, where hee refreÅ¿hed, and the 29. Novem. came by him the Coronel D. van WARDENBURGE, as alÅ¿o did the Commander DIRRICK SYMONSZ come thither the 29. of the Å¿ame moneth, who Å¿ayled out of Texel with the Å¿aid Coronel the 20. October: The Fleet beeing then Å¿trong 50. Ships & PinaÅ¿Å¿es, 2. PryÅ¿es and 13. great Shalloups, where was muÅ¿tered 7280. Men iong and olde, towit 3780 Mariners and 3500 Souldiers. With which Forces according to his order hee Å¿ett his courÅ¿e towards the CoaÅ¿t of Pernambuco, and got land in Å¿ight the 2. February vpon 7. degrees 4. Minutes, and the 13. of February aboute C.S. AuguÅ¿tijn: Where was reÅ¿olued that the Coronell with 16. Ships and PinaÅ¿Å¿es, and 2400. Souldiers and 600. Mariners Å¿hould land 2. mile northwards of Pernambuco in Rio Doce: and the Generall with the reÅ¿t of the Fleete and 2. Å¿trong Companies of Souldiers Å¿hould Å¿aile to the Recif. Which reÅ¿olution beeing taken, the 13. and 14. they prepared themÅ¿elves and all things readie, and the 15. by breake of the daye, with milde weather and a Å¿till Å¿ea, they began there EnterpriÅ¿e, towit the Generall Å¿etting towards the Recif vnto the Barra of Pernambuco, and the Coronell Wardenborge with his 16. Å¿aile, wherein was 2400. Souldiers and 600. Mariners, whoe beeing landed preÅ¿entlie Å¿et forwards to the appointed place.

The Generall came to the Barra aforeÅ¿aid aboute noone, and Å¿ailed with Å¿om Å¿hips cloÅ¿e vnder the Fort, which lies vpon the Recif, vpon which hee plaied with his Ordinance vntill the euening, and likewiÅ¿e vpon the land Forts. The Forts alÅ¿o plaied luÅ¿tilie vpon the Ships and with advantage, for the Ships coulde not Å¿hoote leuel by reaÅ¿on of the wauering of the Å¿ea, and when they lighted vpon the Walls, it made onelie whit Å¿pots without doeing anie damage to the Forts onelie a little at the verie top of the Walles.

6. Ships and 11. PinaÅ¿Å¿es remained readie with Å¿male Å¿aile to run in, when warning Å¿hould bee giueÌ at high water, which was expected aboute 3. of the clock. But the Governour of Pernambuco it Å¿eemes was long afore advertiÅ¿ed of the coming of this Fleete, and therevpon had Å¿topped the mouth of the River of the Recif (namelie the Poco and Barette) with Å¿oncked Ships, and fenced the whole Vilage Povo vpon the land Recif with a little wall or breaÅ¿tworck, Å¿o that the Ships and PinaÅ¿Å¿es at that time could effect nothing, and the other Ships which laye-cloÅ¿e vnder the Wall were conÅ¿trained to drawe back toward the euening.

In the meane while the Coronel Wardenborgh was buÅ¿ie with landing his Forces with Shalloups and Boates at the place appointed, and marched formoÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe with the vantguarde, in Å¿ight of his Enimies, who Å¿hewed themÅ¿elues Å¿trong both a foote and horÅ¿eback along the Å¿trand, wherevpon the reÅ¿t of the Forces followed out of the Ships, with 2 pieces of Ordinance which Å¿hott 3. pound iron, but the euening drawing on, they were conÅ¿trained to lodge one the Å¿trand vnder the Å¿kie that night.

In the night time haueing made all preparation, the morning drawing one hee martched forwards corragiouÅ¿lie with all his Forces, parted in 3. Regiments and a partie of Firelocks, the vantguard vnder which the Coronell was himÅ¿elfe, was commaunded by Lieutennant EltÅ¿z: the Battaillion by
Lieutennant Steyncalenfels, and the rierguard by the Major Houx, haueing on there one Å¿ide a thik groue, out of which they feared much to bee annoyed.

By Rio Doce which is a running River (where they were conÅ¿trained to march through to the middel) they were encountred of the Portingals, who laie there entrenched Å¿ome 1800. Å¿trong, the Å¿kirmidge was hot and ours put back twice, and manie Å¿laine and hurt one both Å¿ides, but moÅ¿t one the Enimies Å¿ide, and Å¿o at laÅ¿t they were put to flight.

From thence the Coronell marched to the Towne without reÅ¿ting, takeing by the waye Å¿ome blaks, but learning noe intelligence from them, coming to the Towne they aÅ¿Å¿aulted the IeÅ¿uites CloÅ¿ter, the gates whereof were bolwerkt toe within Å¿ide, which beeing beaten open and all Å¿laine that reÅ¿iÅ¿ted, the Enimies were forced to forÅ¿ake the CloÅ¿ter, leauing behinde manie dead and maimed.

The Enimies forces in the Trenches and Forts one the Strand along the Sea, heareing Å¿uch newes, and perceiueing Major Houx coming againÅ¿t them with the reareguard, tooke the flight alÅ¿o after a little Å¿kirmidging, and playing of the Ordinance, leaueing behinde them Å¿ome few dead and hurt.

In the meane time that the Coronell approached the Towne one the North Å¿ide, the Generall had landed 2. Companies with good convenience one the South Å¿ide, and Å¿ent them to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the Coronell, and Å¿o the Towne was aÅ¿Å¿aulted one both Å¿ides, in Å¿uch manner that aboute 4. of the clock in the afternoone it was ouercome with loÅ¿Å¿e of aboute 50. or 60. Souldiours.

After the winning of the Towne there was found within but aboute 100. ChiÅ¿ts with Sugar, Å¿ome Wines, little Meal and other Å¿mall matters of little vallew, becauÅ¿e the Cittizens and Inhabitants were fled with moÅ¿t part of there goods, notwithÅ¿tanding the Governour MATTHIAS d'ALBUQUERQUE had forbidden it vpon paine of death, that noe bodie Å¿hould
flie, or carrie ought out of the Towne, becauÅ¿e the Inhabitants might help to keepe the Towne the better.

In the night the Generall cauÅ¿ed the hauen mouthes to be founded, and the Forts to bee viewed, which the Enimie did holde Å¿tronglie beÅ¿et, Å¿o that there was Å¿male hope to doe anie good againÅ¿t them by water.

The 17. February the Governour cauÅ¿ed all the PackhouÅ¿es to bee Å¿et on fire, wherein was aboue 15000. ChiÅ¿ts of Sugar, becauÅ¿e the Inhabitants were fled as a priÅ¿oner reported, which fire coulde not bee hindered by ours.

The 20. after the Towne was well beÅ¿et and good order Å¿et in all things, there was reÅ¿olued by the CounÅ¿ell to make an EnterprinÅ¿e vpon the Fort, which layes vpon the land Recif; where to the Coronel commaunded the Lieutennant Steyncalenfelts with 400. or 500. Men, whoe quited himÅ¿elfe well in that Action, and Å¿tormed twoo houres in the night vpon the Fort, but beeing the Å¿kaling Ladders, which were raiÅ¿ed were found a faddem to Å¿hort, and that the gates coulde not bee opened, becauÅ¿e thoÅ¿e of the Å¿male Fort that lies vpon the Sea Recif, did much annoye ours with there Cannons, wee reÅ¿olued to retraite to Å¿pare our Men, leaueing behinde vs aboute 20. dead and 40. or 50. hurt.

The 21. the Barrette beeing viÅ¿ited with Shalloups, whoe Å¿et fire on the Ship that the Enimies had Å¿unck in the mouth with Å¿tones to Å¿top the paÅ¿Å¿age, which Ship beeing fired, they found good convenience to come within the Recif with Shalloups, but Å¿eeing the Village vpon the Recif, where the PackhouÅ¿es were fired, was Å¿o fenced with Walles, BreÅ¿twoorks and PaliÅ¿ades, it was thought verie dangerous to land there to attempt anie thing againÅ¿t the Village.

And the 22. beeing buÅ¿ie to Å¿trengthen the Towne with more Workes, and alÅ¿o the IeÅ¿uites CloÅ¿ter, and likewiÅ¿e in makeing a Bridge at the Foote of the Towne, which Å¿houlde come out ouer the Bar like a head a little Seawards to land;
and carrie aboord anie thing drie in time of neede.

The 23. was reÅ¿olued with approbation of all the Officers to drawe neare the Fort (that lies vpon the land Recif) with Approaches, whereto all preparation of FoÅ¿Å¿iues and SconcebaÅ¿kets were made, moÅ¿t of the Mariners beeing imployed aboute cutting RijÅ¿work and makeing Sconce-baÅ¿kets, and others finiÅ¿heing of the Å¿aid Bridge.

And the 25. haueing finiÅ¿hed diuers BreÅ¿tworks in manie Å¿treets of the Towne, againÅ¿t anie Å¿uddaine EnterpriÅ¿e of the Enimie, the Approaches towards the greate Fort were began the 29. Februarie by the Lieutennant EltÅ¿z, with 500. Men, who caÅ¿t vp a Trench the Å¿ame night againÅ¿t the Fort, betwixt the Village (that lies vpon the Recif) and the Towne: and the next daye had AlmoÅ¿t finiÅ¿hed a Batterie, when the Major Houx came to relieue him, whereto the Coronell alÅ¿o repaired and remained there vntill the next daye, vntill the Batterie was finiÅ¿hed, and 3. halfe Cartouwes planted, which played the whole daye.

And afterwards beeing the 2. March, haueing played all the morning with the Ordinance, thoÅ¿e of the Fort rolled vp there Auncient, and put out a white Å¿heete and Å¿o Å¿ought to parle, Å¿ending out a Captaine, who agreed with the Coronell to deliuer ouer the Fort vpon Conditions as hereafter follow in the Articles.

This beeing don the Coronell reÅ¿olued to demand vp the Fort which lies vpon the Sea Recif, and therevpon hee advertiÅ¿ed his intent to the Generall and the reÅ¿t of the CounÅ¿ell, who all ratified the Å¿ame, and Å¿o it was put in practiÅ¿e, Å¿ending out a Tambour and an Interpreter, who they of the Fort preÅ¿entlie gaue audience, and Å¿ent out there Lieuten
â¢ ant (taking another in hoÅ¿tage in his place) who agreed with the Coronell in like manner as thoÅ¿e of the other Fort â¢ id, and therevpon marched out.

The next daye beeing the 3. of March the Generall gaue commaundement vnto the Lieutennant Steyncalenfelts, to make en EnterpriÅ¿e vpon the Iland, called Antonie Vaz, cituated ouer againÅ¿t the Village vpon the Recif, where beeing Å¿et ouer hee found noe reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, the Inhabitants beeing fled haueing heard the winning of the CaÅ¿tles, Å¿o hee lodged a Troup of Souldiers in the CloÅ¿ter, which Å¿tands vpon the Iland, where with the Towne and FortreÅ¿Å¿es of Pernambuco are all in hands of the Officers of licenÅ¿ed WeÅ¿t-India Companie, vnder protection of the States Generall and the Prince of Orenge, which God long continu to his glorie.

The Å¿ame daye that the mouth of the Recif was Å¿ounded, Å¿om Ships, PinnaÅ¿Å¿es and all the Shalloups run into the Recif, which is a verie convenient place, not onelie to laye Å¿hips in, but alÅ¿o te make them cleane and keele them, and the Pinnas that Å¿hould depart with the good newes was made cleane there in the Recif, and loaden with Å¿om Sugars. The Lord Generall being lodged in the Povo vpon the Recif: The Coronell in the IeÅ¿uits CloÅ¿ter; and the Lieutennant Coronel vpon the Iland of Antonie Vaz.

div.head: Articles agreed betwixt the Lord Generall H. C. LONCQ, and Coronell WARDENBURGH on the one pertie, and Captaine ANTONIO DE LIMA, Captaine of the Å¿trong Fort S. George, for his MaieÅ¿tie of Spaine, on the other pertie.
div.p: FIrÅ¿t that Captaine ANTONIO DE LIMA doth binde himÅ¿elfe to deliuer ouer to the Lord Generall and Coronel WARDENBURGH the Å¿trong Fort S. George, with all the Ordinance and Amonition whatÅ¿oeuer now in the Å¿aid Fort.

Item that the Å¿aid Captaine Antonio de Lima after delivering ouer of the faid Fort, Å¿hall depart the Å¿ame with all his Souldiers, with there ordinarie Weapons, without Auncient or burning Matches, and Å¿o bee Å¿et ouer with Barques vpon the faÅ¿t Land, to march whither they pleaÅ¿e.

And for Å¿ecuritie of the Å¿aide Barques the Å¿aid Captaine de Lima Å¿hall remaine in hoÅ¿tage till the Barques returne, and then vpon his faithfull oath and Å¿aluation doth promiÅ¿e to returne the Barque (that Å¿hall tranÅ¿port his perÅ¿on) vndamnified.
And further the Å¿aid Captaine de Lima doth promiÅ¿e for him and his Souldiers, not to Å¿erue againÅ¿t the States Generall or the Prince of Orenge in 6. Monethes.

All theÅ¿e Articles are approoued by both perties in the Campe before the Å¿trong Fort S. George the 2. March 1630. And was Å¿ubÅ¿cribed H. C. LONCK, Generall. T. van WARDENBURGH Coronell. And ANT. DE LIMA, Captaine of the Å¿trong Fort S. George.
TheÅ¿e Articles are alÅ¿o agreed vpon betwixt the Å¿aide Generall and Coronell, and Manuel Pacheco el Guyar, Captaine Major, and Pedro BarboÅ¿a Lieutenant of the Fort vpon ScaÅ¿ide.

div.head: HIGH AND MIGHTIE LORDS.
div.p: SEEING that with Gods aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance I haue victoriouÅ¿ly conquered this Towne of FARNABUCCO, I could not omitt according to my duty, participate vnto you, what is paÅ¿Å¿ed therein as farr as preÅ¿ent tyme will permitt.

In the Bay of S. Vincent hauing found the Generall LONCK with his accompanyed Shipps, wee weare in all (after Å¿ome weekes being gathered together 53. Å¿ayles of Shipps, with healthy and Å¿ickly Souldiers, Å¿ayled from thence the 26. Decemb. 1629. towards the coaÅ¿ts of BraÅ¿ill, where wee came the 12. February, in the clymake of 8. degrees, where there came vnto vs Å¿ome Shipps and Pynnaces, which had loÅ¿t vs and weare Å¿ent out before vs, Å¿o that afterwards wee weare 56. Å¿ayle; Whereafter Å¿erious deliberation wee reÅ¿olued to fall vpon the Ennemy in twoo places, to witte I with 2400. Souldiers and 300. Saylers, with 300. Saylers more to the traine being deuided in 16. Shipps, were reÅ¿olued to land about 2. Myles towards the North of Fernambucco: And the Generall LONCK hauing by him two other Å¿trong Companyes in the other Shipps towards the Recyf, hauing reÅ¿olued the 15. February to effect our enterpriÅ¿e. The Generall going to the Recyf, but by reaÅ¿on thoÅ¿e of the CaÅ¿tell had heard of our comming, they had Å¿unck certayne Å¿hipps in the mouth of the Hauen, Å¿o that the Generalls deÅ¿Å¿eyn toock noe effect allbeitt hee did his beÅ¿t indeauours with Å¿hott of Cannon; in the meane tyme in the afternoone I went towards the Å¿hoare in certayne Sloopes, where there did apeare many Souldiers, both foote and horÅ¿e; and being landed in their Å¿ight, wherevpon the reÅ¿t of our Souldiers followed out of the other Shipps with 2. Peeces that Å¿hott 3. lb Iron, and becauÅ¿e it begann to growe euening, wee weare forced to lodge vpon the Å¿trand: Next morning very early I did Å¿end the Boats towards the Shipps, and Å¿eparated my Troupes in three Regiments.
The Auantguarde where I was in perÅ¿on, aÅ¿well in marching as in landing, was commaunded by Leftennant EltÅ¿z: The Battell by Leftennant Steyncallenfells: The Rierguarde by Major Houcks, marching on the Å¿trand towards the Towne, comming by Rio Dolce was a Å¿male Riuer, which wee weare forced to wade to the middle in water, where wee had the firÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ault, wheare the Ennemy as I am aduiÅ¿ed weare about 1800 Men, both foote and horÅ¿e, did reÅ¿iÅ¿t vs but after a hard SkermiÅ¿h, and many being dead and hurt on both Å¿ides, but leaÅ¿t of our Å¿ide they weare putt to flight. NotwithÅ¿tanding they had a running Riuer for their aduantage. Comming Å¿omwhat further, Å¿tood another Troupe vpon the Å¿trand, but after little reÅ¿iÅ¿tance did alÅ¿o retired in the Woods, Å¿howing themÅ¿elues the third tyme, durÅ¿t not Å¿tay for vs; Å¿o that with all diligence Å¿eing them Å¿o frighted, I marched towards the Towne, drawing neare therevnto with the Auantguarde and Battaille, did amount vnto the IeÅ¿uitts CloyÅ¿ter, where the Backgates weare bollwarckt, and wee in clyming, Å¿awe them in the CloyÅ¿ter arme themÅ¿elues, but after Å¿ome reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and hauing Å¿eene our courage, they fleyed, leauing behind them many dead and wounded, and of our Men weare alÅ¿o Å¿ome Å¿layne. In the meane tyme the Trenches and Fortes haueing notice heereof, and Å¿eing the Rearguarde, making Å¿o haÅ¿tily vpon them, after many Å¿hott with Canon, and Å¿ome dead and hurt, did alÅ¿o flie away, leauing behinde them their Fortes which weare, after Å¿trenghtened by our Men, and Å¿o with Gods mercy are become MaÅ¿ters of the Towne, hauing loÅ¿t in all about 50. or 60. Men.

I haue beÅ¿ett the IeÅ¿uits CloyÅ¿ter (where I am lodged) with Trenches. The 20. February with conÅ¿ent of the CounÅ¿ell; wee did commaund Leftennant Steyncallenfells to make an EnterpriÅ¿e in the night vpon the Forte that Å¿tands vpon the Recyf towards the land, whoe hath quitted himÅ¿elfe therein, and Å¿tormed therevpon twoo houres long, but our lathers
being to Å¿horte, was thought good to retire, to Å¿aue our men with the loÅ¿Å¿e of 20. dead and 40. hurt of our Men, and 12. of theirs. Wherevpon the 23. February hauing thought fitting with conÅ¿ent of the CounÅ¿ell, to fall vpon the Å¿ayd Towne with Approaches, wherevpon preÅ¿ent order was given forâª preparation therevnto, which being done the 27. Februaryâª wee begann the Worke vnder commaund of Leftennant EltÅ¿z, who made the Å¿ame night a Trench againÅ¿t the CaÅ¿tell, betweene this Towne and the Recyf, and the day following the Battery allmoÅ¿t finiÅ¿hed, and when Major Houcx went to relieue him, I went thether alÅ¿o and Å¿tayed there till the day following till the Battery was finiÅ¿hed: and three half Cannon planted therevpon, and hauing Å¿hott all that day and next day being the Å¿econd currant, hauing alÅ¿o Å¿hott the whole morning till about 9. a cloack, began to parle with mee, and Å¿ett vp a white Å¿heete, Å¿ending a Captaine vnto vs with whom I haue agreed, that they leauing the Forte, Å¿hall departe without ancient or burning Matches, leauing behinde them all Artillery, as alÅ¿o all Amunition and ProviÅ¿ion, which wee thinck they haue caÅ¿te in the Sea and carryed away, becauÅ¿e wee found none therein. Further wee urged them to promiÅ¿e not to rayÅ¿e any Armes againÅ¿t the States in 6. Moneths. This being done, wee thought fitting to demaund the other CaÅ¿tel vpon the Recyf, which layes in the Sea.
